questions.question_text: What are two benefits of edge architecture? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
"Data management" is correct for different reasons (collection, processing, analysis, storage, transfer).
I'm wondering between "offline support" and "secure access", as both are very vague and could be correct. I will go with "Secure access", sounds more likely than "Offline support".
Could someone provide a better solution/reason please?

Selected Answer: DE
I don't think "Secure Access" is a benefit of Edge Computing, unless there's something missing in the answer. It's too generic.

"Offline Support" makes more sense to me, as data is processed locally and not sent to a cloud, at least on a regular basis.

"Data Management" seems to be the only other valid option to me. However, there may be something missing in the answer.

Answer is C. 
Watch "Getting NETCONF Data with NCCLIENT" video on CBT Nuggets.

comments.content: C has the status as “Up”, I think it would be “1” instead.

discussion.content:
Answer should be D
it has interface name
admin status is 1
and index is 1 in line with Yang model

comments.content:
admin status 1 is wrong - it needs to be either up, down or testing
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7950#section-9.6.5

discussion.content:
Answer is C.
You can verify it online here:
https://www.netconfcentral.org/tools/yanglint/

Why are the others not correct?
A and D:
<admin-status>1</admin-status> is invalid
only the lexical representations "up, down, testing" are allowed.
(https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7950#section-9.6.5)

B:
The <statistics> container is missing, which should contain <in-octets> and <in-unicast-pkts>

comments.content: <admin-status>1</admin-status> is invalid it's not invalid because it's based on the provided file enum up = 1 enum down =2 enum testing = 3

discussion.content:
I think A is correct.
You can put "name" info either as an attribute or as a child element of "interface"

https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_dtd_el_vs_attr.asp

here's an example and comments on this website.
A.
<person sex="female">
 <firstname>Anna</firstname>
 <lastname>Smith</lastname>
</person>

B.
<person>
 <sex>female</sex>
 <firstname>Anna</firstname>
 <lastname>Smith</lastname>
</person>
In the first example sex is an attribute. In the last, sex is a child element. 
Both examples provide the same information.

A is correct!

B and C have admin status as UP. whereas value should be 1. D has syntax error>>.

comments.content:
indeed there is a double >> but:
A has the interface name as a tag instead of a value
B and C have state as "up" instead of an integer
I think the syntax error in D is the smallest issue and probably just a bad copy of the actual question

discussion.content: It should be D i think as asmin status should be 1,2or 3 according to the actual status given the value inside the enum.

C is correct
lines keys:
<admin-status>up</admin-status>
<statistics>
 <in-octets>408164820</in-octets>
 <in-unicast-pkts>728061</in-unicast-pkts>
</statistics>
Ref: https://blogs.cisco.com/developer/363-yangsuite-01
 https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7950.txt
Answer is C , verified with yangsuite

Answer is between C and D.
D has a syntax error.
C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

4.2.2.3 ... "A container node is used to group related nodes in a subtree. A
 container has only child nodes and no value. A container may contain
 any number of child nodes of any type (including leafs, lists,
 containers, and leaf-lists)."

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6020.html#section-4.2.2.3

comments.content:
4 should be response.text
If use json, it should have () after json like response.json()
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/response-text-python-requests/
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/response-json-python-requests/
plus he would need to import the json first

Almost correct:

1. import

discussion.content:
1. import
2. dict()
3. return
4. text

Can anyone comment on this?

import requests, getpass # This fills the first blank with 'import'

url = 'https://<ipaddress>/restconf/data/Cisco-IOS-XE-native:native/interface/TwentyFiveGigE=1%2F1%2F2'
def askCredentials():
 user = input('Username: ')
 password = getpass.getpass('Password: ')
 return (user, password) # 'return' is already correctly placed in the function

def getRequest(url, credentials):
 headers = dict() # This fills in with 'dict()' to initialize the headers dictionary
 headers['Accept'] = 'application/yang-data+json'
 return requests.get(url, headers=headers, auth=credentials, verify=False) # This fills in with 'return'

creds = askCredentials()
response = getRequest(url, creds)
if response.status_code == 200:
 print(response.text) # This fills in with 'text' to print the response body
